text:
Try blog_tags, but keep in mind that it is a function:
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/functions#blog-tags>
When a user submits a form, the form snippet I'm using has a redirect link. Can custom script be used to have that link open in a new tab instead?
Hi All ! Itâ€™s possible to set search results to not search through navigation/footer  ?

Is there any documentation of `load_translations()` function? It is used this way
`{% set template_translations = load_translations('../_locales', html_lang, 'en') %}` .

Is there a way to filter a `for loop` based on the name of a value? For example:

`{% for project in projects %}`
`{% if project.public_status_name is Design %}`
`<p>test</p>`
`{% endif %}`
`{% endfor %}`

I have tried the string in quotes like project.public_status_name is "Design" but no success yet

try
``` {% if project.public_status_name == "Design" %} ```
More Info: <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/if-statements>
Hm... am getting blank results on that syntax. But there are definitely values named Design
Any other suggestions?
is "public_status_name" correct?
have you tried |pprint to see what is in "project" ?
Correct -- if I print `{{ projects }}` I see this
ah ok
there is also "containing" maybe that helps?

Hm.. I tried with containing but nothing either

`{% if project.public_status_name is containing Design %}`
`{% if project.public_status_name is containing "Design" %}`
Strange
"iterable" ?
If you do `{{ project.public_status_name.foo() }}` what error message do you get in the design manager?
no error but I just noticed the warning - its saying it cant resolve property but I am pulling it in on the `{% set %}` via line 4

<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/functions#crm-objects>
You need to use `{% for project in projects.results %}`
Ah! Thats my mistake I had that, I've been tweaking around must have not reverted
Am still getting blank results -- should I see an error on the front end or design with the `.foo()` command?
What do you see if you output `{{ project }}`?
didn't see anything but I did some tweaking and think I got it working!
changed to `projects.results`  based on your {{ project }} output
thank you :slightly_smiling_face: to you both
Cool. If `public_status_name` is just a string, `{% if project.public_status_name == 'Design' %}` should work for you as well

Is it possible to alter if it actually just contains the word and not it specifically? For example if I have two records, such as `Architecture Design` and `Web Design`  and want to get both from Design word
`{% if project.public_status_name is string_containing 'Design' %}` or `{% if project.public_status_name is containing 'Design' %}`  should work for that
Appreciate your help, got it thank you :slightly_smiling_face:

How would you go about building a module or an editable area of a page that never needs to be used again? Modules are re-usable but this just needs to be an editable section. Can you point me to the right guide if there is one?

Last question involving syntax if anyone can help! I had to revise my `if statement` query but I'm stuck on the correct "" syntax. Shouldn't it be `project.zip_code is containing ~contact.zip`? If I am targeting the contact zipcode property?
Just realized I guess && operator does not work in hubl

Im trying to do it this way but don't know how to target the current blog tag:

<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/guides/creating-a-related-post-listing>

&& operator works. Try

`project.zip_code is containing contact.zip`

or

`project.zip_code is containing "{{ contact.zip }}"`
Ah it does? Thank you :slightly_smiling_face:
What are you expecting the `~` to do? It is the concatenation operator
So it looks like `{{contact.zip}}` performs the same way as I'm pulling the zip property correctly

If I use it in conjunction with the last request: `{% if project.public_status_name is string_containing 'Bidding' && project.zip_code is string_containing '{{ contact.zip }}' %}`  it's not pulling filtering from both (bidding + the zipcode)

Nested expressions are an anti-pattern that you should avoid if possible. Using that won't work here due to `{{ }}` not being valid EL syntax.
You'd just want `{% if project.public_status_name is string_containing 'Bidding' && project.zip_code is string_containing contact.zip %}`
This message was deleted.
Pretty easy to if you can put it in the url
just have the internal property name as the key and the value as the object id
otherwise you might need to get a little complicated with javascript
Ah I understand!
I think this one works :slightly_smiling_face:
Really appreciate it Jack
